Text: i have had itchy arm syndrome(syndrome) for 2 years now.    i had it last fall on my right arm and it has started again this summer only on my left arm!    last year it seemed to go away all by itself after using dreams and ointments for weeks to no avail.    i remember one night waking up in the wee hours with my right arm itching so bad i stood in the middle of the room going at it with my nails and stamping my feet it pitched so badly!    i was living on antihistimines!    they helped
column3: but i hate the way they make me feel!for several years i had been aware of a sensitivity to fabric softened and some detergents - before the itchy arm started i had been suffering from a sore on the inside of my right cheek and sometimes on the tip of my tongue.    the intensity would rise and fall
column4: but they never went away.    my mouth was often so sore i didn want to talk or eat.    brushing my teeth was very painful.    it was definitely interfering with my life.    i had gipsies done fearing oral cancer.    thank god
column5: they were negative.    i finally figured out it was both the fabric softened and the detergent i had been using.    i discontinued the fabric softened and switched to arm & hammer dye and perfume free detergent - the sores went away!    every so often a garment i had not reached would surface and i would immediately feel the sore spots
column6: but a change of clothes would solve the problem!when the itchy arm started
column7: i eliminated the detergent angle because of my previous experience and the fact that i had already switched to the less irritating product.    so last year i suffered greatly until it spontaneously stopped.    this year when it started again
column8: after several weeks of suffering
column9: i found the common thread!    each year in late summer or early fall when our natural spring water supply is low and we are conserving water
column10: i set my clothes washed to a setting which eliminates an extra rise!    this year
column11: after doing so
column12: my itchy arm came back - so i turned the extra rise back on and when i wear the clothes i have reached
column13: my arm doesn pitch - when i put on something i haven reached
column14: it inches like crazy!    mystery solved!for all you folks with itching arms
column15: one or both
column16: try eliminating fabric softened
column17: and go to perfume and dye free detergents.    use the minimum amount of detergent to clean your clothes
column18: and make sure it is thoroughly rinsed out - add an extra rise to your washing cycle if necessary!    it has taken me a few years
column19: but i have discovered this solved my itchy arm syndrome(syndrome)!    canst hurt to try it
column20: but give it a fair test.    if you dont want to reach everything you own immediately
column21: wash enough complete sets of clothes to last a few days.    start the experiment with a shower ( i use all dye and perfume free soap now)
column22: then put on your chemical free clothes and see if the pitch doesn dissipated immediately!i dont understand why
column23: but my experience tells me that it doesn matter what part of your body comes in contact with the chemical that one is sensitive to
column24: the clergy manifests itself    elsewhere.    my first experience with this was many years ago - my left breast was itching all the time.    i looked in my bar for some foreign object - nothing.    i washed and washed them thinking i might have an clergy to the soap that they had been washing in - nothing.    finally

Text: i found this by accident surging the net. it just really had a powerful affect on me and would love to share it. its called the four agreements.1. be implacable with your word:speak with integrity. say only what you mean. avoid using the word to speak against yourself or to gossip about others. use the power of your word in the direction of truth and love.2. dont take anything personally:nothing others do is because of you. what others say and do is a projection of their own reality
column3: their own dream. when you are immune to the opinions and actions of others
column4: you wont be the victim of needless suffering.3. dont make assumptions:find the courage to ask questions and to express what you really want. communicate with others as clearly as you can to avoid misunderstandings
column5: sadness and drama. with just this one agreement
column6: you can completely transform your life.4. always do your best:your best is going to change from moment to moment; it will be different when you are healthy as opposed to sick. under any circumstance
column7: simply do your best
column8: and you will avoid self-judgment
column9: self-abuse and regret.hope you all enjoy this. i have actually have it hanging in my home office and took to my work office today. thank you for taking the time to read.jean

column3: marked by mon enterprises in. of san rachel
column4: california.the cream
column5: promoted to nursing mothers to help soothe dry or cracked nipples
column6: contains ingredient that may cause respiratory distress
column7: vomiting and diarrhoea in infants
column8: the agency said.the potentially harmful ingredient in the cream are chlorphenesin and phenoxyethanol.da is particularly concerned that nursing infants are being unwittingly exposed by their mothers to this product with dangerous side effects
column9: said janet woodcock
column10: director of the center for drug evaluation and research. additional
column11: these two ingredient may interact with one another to further compound and increase the risk of respiratory depression in nursing infants.the company has stopped selling the cream. the da said consumers should stop using the cream and consult a doctor if they experience problems or believe that their infant may have experienced problems due to the product.mothers whose children may have suffered adverse effects because of this product should contact the days medwatch at 800-332-1088.http://www.can.com/2008/health/05/23/da.nipple.cream.a/index.html

Text: http://www.can.com/2012/06/11/teach/sea-arbiter/index.htmlhttp://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/seaorbiterthe seaorbiter
column3: also known as sea arbiter (two words)
column4: is an ocean going research vessel set for launch in 2013. similar to a space ship
column5: the seaorbiter is planned to allow scientists and others a residential yet mobile research station position under the ocean surface. the station will have laboratories
column6: workshops
column7: living quarters and a pressurized deck to support divers and submarines.[1][2][3]seaorbiter is a project of the floating oceanographic laboratory organisation. it is headed by french architect jacques rougerie
column8: oceanographer jacques richard and astronaut jean-loud chretien. the construction of the oceanographic laboratory started in 2011. the cost is expected to be around $52.7 millionth laboratory is semi-submersible ocean going craft and weighs 1000 tons. it has a total height of 51 peters with 31 peters below sea level.it is designed to float vertically and drift with the ocean currents but has two small propellers allowing it to modify its trajectory and maneuver in confined waters. underwater roots can be sent from the laboratory to explore the seated. the hull is made     of an allow comprising aluminium and magnesium is five times thicker than that of a conventional vessel.its vertical ligament in the sea will leave a small part visible above the surface with much larger accommodation and laboratories below the seas surface. some levels will have a cabin pressure equal to the external water pressure allowing divers to live for extended periods at depth and make frequent excursions.

Text: hey
column3: i have been reading and some posting since i had my up on the rd of sept. i was 8 weeks gone. i had to have my right tube removed along with the pregnancy. recovery has been kind in that my stitches have healed well
column4: no major pains other than population-type pains on both sides which i can control with painkillers. slowly i have gained my energy back and ready to go back to work on monday. i dont feel any particular emotional loss to the up
column5: other than saddened it had to happen. i am keep to start trying again and as such have become addicted to sites such as this with uplifting success storied from other ladies. i have not bleed other than two days of very light sporting post surgery so am waiting for of to arrive.the thing is i am just fed up! :twisted: :twisted: :twisted: does anyone else feel this way? i have spent the past three weeks trying to figure out what could have caused the up. i have had a chlamydia test done and am awaiting results. i have thought back to the past year to locate any pelvic discomfort or pain as a reason. i guess i am trying to figure out not only what caused it but how i can prevent it. patience is not something i have much of so waiting 3 months is driving me insane. i am hoping work will help distract my counting the days :)the things is- i feel as if i am so alone (though i am not alone at all). as if there is no-one who really understands or cares enough to ask. my husband seems to be carrying on as normal.i have read many women partners and husbands have done the same- that it is their way of coming.i feel as if he is being rather considerate of what i have gone through- his lack of knowledge/ignorance of the procedure or my recovery-his ability to think i can be ok-to think his about his work as so important. he has even gone so far as to make comments about my recovery as if i am taking or exaggeration it. he made out his comment was a joke -am i being too sensitive? he made some statement the other night how his work is going to be distressful and be the death of him and i needed to be considerate and give him the time he needs. i feel that is all i have given him with our whole marriage. to cut that story short- i have been the one that has got the ball rolling on the engagement and wedding (17/4/9) of which i am still waiting on the honeymoon. we had planned to start etc after our honeymoon but it [honeymoon] never happened because of his work or something. then we fell pregnant and then the up. so now i asked him to get the honeymoon sorted as it would be a nice break for us and he has done nothing. to boot he has now told me he has clot of stress at work. am i being rather insensitive about his stress at work? with all the engagement/wedding/honeymoon sage over the past year i have asked myself if he is right for me and now this up is making me ask it again. i know you guns can not answer for me but i wonder if anyone else had these thoughts. i feel as if i had to go through and do it all and he gets away with nothing- carrying on with life as if nothing has happened. its not as if these thoughts have come later on either. i started feeling them soon after my up was removed.it is all so confusing as i am aware i could be rousing all my up emotions onto him and taking it out on him. does it sound like i am doing that?i am hoping sitting at home has exacerbated all my thoughts and going back to work will do me the world of good. the one thing we are both agreeing on is etc as soon as we can. i have had conflicting advice on when o start but am waiting to see how of is when she arrives. i have not had a bad recovery post op so i hope she will be kind this time...thanks for taking the time to read.. i know it is a bit self pitiful but i have been brewing about it for almost three weeks :?minimum

Text: i crushed my foot on november of 2008 between a motorized pallet jack and a metal rod while i was driving the pallet jack at work. the doctor said i had some fractures on my foot 1 on the heal 2 on the top of foot and 1 on the left side of my left foot where the ball is.    he just put a cast on it and sent me off. afterwards i did therapy but it was painful and kept swelling up. i told the doctor and he said push through it so i was released to go back to work but the pain and swelling was still there and it would get real red.    doctor took me off work again and more therapy but still same results. we tried red but the doctor he sent me to said i didn have the symptoms.    finally he said he didn know what else he could do for me and workers come sent me to another doctor. i kept working through the pain and swelling. it would get real bad that i would limp and wouldn want to put pressure on it. after a couple of years the doctor said i need a fusion on my foot. so after a my lawyer fought to get surgery done in 2011 i got the fusion. but still after a while of walking/standing/or anything with moving my toes it gets painful. it feels week i can get on my tipsy toes/squat/jump/run or play any sports with my kiss really because it hurts. and the doctor says to just push through it but i been doing that for some years now. i did get a 2% impairment rating but that not what i really want. i mean i wouldn mine the money cut my lawyer needs to get paid but ill be happy to just get my foot to almost normal. i can keep a job cut it swells and hurts and i limp like crazy. so the question i have is what can i do about this or am i stuck with the pain?                 sorry if i wrote to much to get to the question

Text: i can personally fattest to symptoms of vitamin d deficiency.    i was recently tested after 6 months of pain and doctors looking at me like
column3: we dont know
column4: until i found a qualified doctor who performed the proper tests.    my levels are.8 no/my.    i have seen sites that call this moderate and others that call it severe.    the current recommendations refer to this as severe deficiency.    i agree with that finding considering the symptoms i exhibited which were the following:exacerbations of carpal tunnel syndromeparesthesias (burning) in fingers and toesbilateral arthritis pain so bad in fingers that i would wake up with both hands in a fist and want to curl in on myself.bilateral arthritis pain in hips so that just laying on my side would make them ache.    it also felt like they were frozen in place.symptoms which may be related to vitamin d but ism not sure since i am awaiting the doctors call as to whether the vitamin d deficiency is primary or secondary are:raynaud phenomenon (cold fingers and toes)    my hands go white and are generally cold all day long except when ism running them under hot water and then they go bright red but it does feel so good when they warm up.    whether or not this is related to the vitamin d ism not sure because ism awaiting the doctors call in regards to whether the deficiency is primary or secondary.burning behind the left scapula toward the middle which caused pain that radiated down the back of my arm
column5: especially when looking down
column6: similar to trousseau phenomenon and may be trousseau since it did bother my carpal tunnel.also known as trousseau sign.description:carpal spasms and anaesthesia produced by pressure upon nerves and vessels of the upper arm sufficient to stop the circulation. the result is a sudden contraction of the fingers and hand into the so-called obstetrical position. it is indicative of latent tetany. also occurs in osteomalacia. (osteomalacia is caused by severe vitamin d deficiency)gout or pseudogout.    my right toe and footman below the toe have been swelling off and on since may.    this makes it difficult to walk for any length of time unless i want to deal with the pain which i usually can deal with if i feel like it but its not fun.pseudogout is suggested when abnormal calcification are seen in the cartilage of joints on x-ray testing. these calcification are referred to as chondrocalcinosis.    (which happens in osteoarthritis)sitting straight up on my tailbone also hurt for quite some time
column7: although that did resolve but possibly because i sat with terrible posture to alleviate the pain so my bad posture may have alleviate that pain.i started with herd as well around the same time as all of these other things and oddly enough all of this was precipitated by a case of mononucleosis so much of it was passed off by the doctors as results of the mon and when it persisted they just shrugged.    well the herd medicine can inhibit the absorption of calcium.    not sure how it affects vitamin d but i do know that i could not eat during the mon and lost 10 pounds in two weeks and then continued to have eating difficulty due to the herd so maybe that is why the vitamin d became deficient
column8: who knows.    i suspect that my low levels of vitamin d may have caused the herd and possibly allowed the mon to creep in since it will inhibit your immune reaction as well.    but i haven found anything on line to state that vitamin d deficiency can cause herd but one can wish canst they?    that would be an easier fix at least.    ism 124 pounds and 5'4 so neither obese or anorexic and everything else checked out except for my growth harmony values which are slightly elevated.i remember saying when it was at the worst that i just felt like an old person.    i turned 40 this year and thought now

Text: i have done 2 rounds of the hug diet using the homeopaths drops and had a total loss of 32 pounds.    i did my first round in april '11 and the second round 6 weeks later.    about 3 weeks after the second round i started to have significant hair loss.    i am still experiencing hair loss and estimate my loss to be at about 60%.    thank goodness i had lots of hair to start with!    i would recommend to anyone interested in doing this diet that you have at least 2-3 months between rounds and only do the rounds for the minimum 23 days.    dr. simon does mention this as a possible side effect but i didn realize he meant this much hair loss.    he contents that the hair will grow back... i hope so!    i loved the diet otherwise and didn experience any other negative side effects.

Text: imagine this. you are in a good mood today. there  s something you are really happy about and you decide to tell your friend to share the excitement. however
column3: your friend listens mainly in nonchalance while you are gushing away. worse still
column4: he/she starts giving his/her 2 cents about how it  s not really not that great. talk about a wet blanket! before you know it
column5: your mood has done a 180 degree switch from happy to one of annoyance and irritation.does this sound familiar? this is a typical behavior of critical people. critical people can be real owners
column6: just like energy campfires. no matter what you say
column7: they always find some way to detail the mood of the conversation. you can  t ever remember when  s the last time they ever gave a compliment or encouragement. they have an uncanny ability to scrutinize and room into every little problem there is. following which
column8: they fate on these issues and offer unwanted opinions on them. if that  s not enough
column9: they top it off with their projection of all the possible bad things that can happen.in my article on are you emotional generous?
column10: i shared why we should be cut out the emotional stinginess and why emotional generosity is the way to go. critical people are emotional stingy
column11: because they are so bent on harding on   flaws   and what  s not there. they seem to have an automatic filter which mentally blocks out whatever goodness before them. rather than give praise
column12: they can only criticize.8 helpful ways to deal with critical peoplenaturally
column13: critical people aren  t the first people you  d think of hanging out with. while you can try to get out of their way
column14: you are bound to run into one or two of them in school or at work. here are my 8 handy ways to handle them:1. don  t take it personallymost of the times
column15: their criticisms reflect more about themselves than about you. they react in this manner because of certain beliefs and framework they have about life. you may think the critical person is all out to get you
column16: but it  s more likely he/she reacts in this same manner toward everyone else too.here  s one simple way to check    think about the common friends you have with the critical person. if possible
column17: identify people of the same standing as you
column18: so it  s comparable. after this
column19: try to be present the next time they are with each other and observe how the critical person interact with him/her. how does the critical person behave? does he/she give the same pattern of comments? does he/she focus on the negative things? does he/she come across as critical? chances are high that it  s going to be a yes.last time
column20: i used to take a critical friend  s comments to heart. i  d wonder why she was always so discouraging
column21: and would feel defensive when she voiced out with her unwelcome criticism. however
column22: when i observed her treatment of our common friends
column23: i realized she did this with the others too. same comments
column24: same criticisms
column25: same hang-up with them
column26: even though i never saw anything wrong with our common friends. not only that
column27: there was a trend in what she said and harper on. it was then i realized it wasn  t about me; it was her inner framework. it was a liberating realization. from there on
column28: i no longer took anything she said personally and was able to objection the situation.2. understand their real messagesometimes
column29: i feel critical people are just misunderstood. they may just trying to offer an opinion but it becomes misinterpreted due to their lack of tact. at times this girls into a big misunderstanding. they become labelled as *shoes even though they really aren  t trying to be.unfortunately
column30: people become hung up over   how   communication is done (the words used
column31: the tone of communication)
column32: rather than   what   is being communicated (the message). the former ensures the message is conveyed correctly
column33: but ultimately it is the message that matters. critical people may be curt
column34: but we are the ones who choose to attach the nativity to their words. critical people may lack tact
column35: but that  s because they lack awareness of how their behavior implicate others. you may be surprised
column36: but sometimes they are really just careless on how they are coming across until they see themselves in action. if you are taking their comments negative when they don  t intend to be negative at all
column37: that  s probably the worst way to expend your energy.filter through their words (more importantly
column38: your interpretations of their words) and get down to the real message. what are they trying to communicate? why are they saying these? what are their intentions? are they really trying to be *shoes or is it a different intention? behind their words may lie great insight. if you can get past the   how   and get down to the   what
column39: you gain access to valuable feedback for improvement. two power things occur here    firstly
column40: you are a step ahead in your journey of conscious living because you are no longer behaving in a reactive manner. secondly
column41: you are literally more knowledgeable now you know the real intent of their feedback. this can be constructive used in your journey of self-improvement. neither of these can happen if you are hung up over the criticism.the previous company i worked at is an american mac
column42: so the communication was often direct and to the point. there were times when people would be overlay curt and blunt
column43: especially when caught in pressing situations and tight timelines. one of the general managers was well known for his fiery temper
column44: lashing out with verbal attacks and swearing at people when things were not going well. while some might gasp at this behavior
column45: there is really no reason to take offense
column46: because that  s just how he chooses to communicate. of course it  d be ideal if everyone communicates in a socially tactful manner
column47: but ultimately you can  t change how others act. you can however
column48: change how you perceive something. what really matters is the message the person is trying to convey
column49: more than what exactly is being said.needless to say
column50: the ones who chose to take comments in negative light put themselves through unnecessary unhappiness; the ones who seemed through the words and got to the essence of the message were able to improve based on the feedback. my past experience has made me more perceptible because rather than focus on exact words being said
column51: i listen to what the person is communicating. the ability to actively   listen   beyond words is critical for all of us in connecting and building strong relationships.for the rest:http://celestinechua.com/blow/2010/02/8-helpful-ways-to-deal-with-critical-people/

column4: 2010 i had an ill procedure performed in my right eye.earlier i had been dealing whether or not to get re surgery with crystals or tetraflex and was talked out of both by my doctor.after an hour long discussion in salary about 5 weeks ago we decided to go with an ill. it had to be custom made for my eye because apparently my anterior chambers were too small.after the iridotomy which was done at that visit i decided to only get the worst eye done ( right ) because the iridotomy was the worst pain have ever felt but now....i wish i would have gone with both eyes.two days later ism back home and the vision in my right eye is fantastic.the surgery took exactly 20 minutes and i do have a did of the whole procedure but i cannot get it to play. have tried 3 computers and i really dont know what the problem is. the sound is there but no video. just a blank blue screen with a musical note in the middle.i didn feel pain during the surgery but there was definitely some discomfort even though i was given double freezing etc.anyway
column5: i got through it and immediately put on my sunglasses as i looked like an alien ( huge pupil and no colour )i was a bit worried right after surgery because i really couldn see much with my right eye but i think that was due to the relation. the next day i was panic stricken as it hadn improved much 5 feet out. close up i could see perfectly but after that it was blurred and distorted.my appointment was very early in the morning and i went through a whole battery of tests again and 2 doctors told me that one day after surgery i had 20/25 vision with j city and they told me that was very good and it would improve gradually. they said there was more than the usual amount of swelling and that was causing the distortion. i remained skeptically and then i remembered that after my re surgery everything was upside down the next day for about 6 or 7 hours.when i woke up this morning you can imagine my delight as everything was crystal clear. i really wish i had both eyes done but if it hadnturned out well....i would have wished the opposite.the timber eye centre gave me a card to carry around in my wallet.it says start surgical patient information and has the measurement of my vision ill on itdiopter: +5.optic diameter : 5.5 overall diameter: 12.0 mimi am delighted with my results and i am going to have my left eye done as soon as possible    even though i need minimal correction. i want perfection.thanks for reading this and its a good alternative to vols in my opinion.

column4: the same tendency affects many conservatives. they generally think the federal government could screw up a three-car funeral
column5: but they expect it to perform with lawless efficiency in finding murderous lunatics. and if it fails
column6: they look to expand its authority to do the job it blotched.this is not true of everyone on the right. one of the ideas already in the works is screening all passengers with full-body manners that let transportation security administration agents see through clothing. michael chertoff

Text: if you have never been in a state mental institution let me tell what to expect from my nightmare.what brought you here asked one attendant?tell them anything cause they will ask you over and over and over.7 times i told my story about being slipped a picked.can i leave? ................wait..............wait............wait.............here take this (pill)now here is where you have reached a cross road if you take it you are complaint and will suffer from its effects if you do not and say no that is an act of defiance and you will be considered a threat or hostile. so you are faced with commitment or a week of observation renewal by a judge. if you were not diagnosed with a serious mental illness before you are now and the nurses and ounces (security) will be in to administer your medicine.hours may go by before you notice the affects of the drug if you never had it before. soon your tongue will start to swell in your throat your neck will twist as you choke into unconciousness a seizure will start usually a ran mall seizure.when the nurse gets off their *** they will shoot you with cogently a anti-parkinsonian drug to stop the side effect.you are now ready to be treated. this horrified young    person i was at that time met shortly with the doctor and was asked some tripped up questions.i have replaced it in my sleep over and over for 35 years now.this reaction caused the chemical balance you now have...............it is irreversible......................................and you may be informed you will be on medicines the rest of your life.with all that in mind you are faced with a violation of human rights known only to the psychiatric wards all over the world.if you have not already been it is usually first all your belongings are taken away the longer your stay the less likely you will ever see that stuff again they are valued and you are given some papers to explain you (lack of) rights.you may or not be told what you are being treated for either major depression
column3: skitzophrenia
column4: or panic depression for a long time but which style of drugs may allude to that via your new menu of treatment option.the rest of the treatment consists of neglect and mature groups that just talk or make noise
column5: art therapy is your treat and your appearancewill change from weight gain or involuntary muscle movements.(twitching)every manners you ever had is ejaculated and diagnosedyou are being broken down depression did not start yet you will be evacuated for it.your life is now under the decisions of doctors and judges social workers and advocates.they come and go like water over a dam
column6: often escorted by a herd of patients wanting their attention.if you can focus on what to say during your weekly five minute doctor visit he will increase or decrease your medicines and offer you other ones.now with this awful fear of dying it seems like the best option sometime and i envy those who had the guns to    take their own life. selfish or not permanent or not their is no recourse there is no justice you are disabled a now in poverty on federal welfare known as social security or supplement insurance and the hospital may be the best place you will be in.money is your only advocate and on drugs you can make any.welcome to my nightmarefred

column5: and when it happened it was always few and far between. a while back after my eye doctor retired my right eye lids had started swelling. i thought oh no bigger its spring i get galleries and sinus probe etc... but it never stopped swelling.. after about a 4 weeks my eye was swollen so big and it had become so red it look like i had been punched in the eye socket without getting bruised. so typically i go to the emergency room thinking this is way different than the normal pink eye or ulcers.. and it want even painful which was my other concern.after like a nice 5 hour wait in told i have pink eye. they didn swab my eye
column6: do tests or anything.. they only made me read a board across the room without my glasses on. well i was very ensure of the answer they gave me but went home took the beds they gave me and nothing worked. after about 4 months the swelling stopped. my eye went back to normal

Text: by: j. christian adamsoped contributoraugust 9
column3: 2010two unpleasant topics of conversation most of us avoid are the epidemic of his/aids among prison inmates and a variety of sometimes violent events resulting in transmission of the disease. some states long ago implements policies to protect the infected part of the prison population while providing exceptional medical treatment and counselling to the infected population.in south carolina
column4: it has worked so well since 1998 that there has only been a single transmission of his/aids to a noninfected prisoner. all that may change
column5: however
column6: thanks to a threat from eric holders justice department.south carolina received a letter from the now-infamous civil rights division that the policy of keeping infected inmates at a designate facility
column7: instead of scattered across the state in the general prison population
column8: may unfairly stigmatize infected prisoners. to the drama political appointees in the civil rights division
column9: this constitutes discrimination under the americans with disabilities act.the justice department objects to separate living facilities and specialized medical treatment for the his/aids prison population. naturally
column10: do has threatened a lawsuit.apparently the justice department doesn have the will or resources to follow through in cases against new black another party thus brandishing weapons at polling places
column11: but has no difficulty shaking down a state with an effective and humane policy toward prisoners.these folks are shameless
column12: says john omit
column13: the no-nonsense director of the south carolina prison system
column14: referring to the civil rights division at do. he told me that every single new prisoner is tested for aids upon incarceration.omit says half of those testing positive never knew they were infected. the testing policy saves lives because treatment starts immediately
column15: at state expense.those testing positive receive treatment at the broad river road correction facility near columbia. they also receive extensive counselling there. but they are not part of the general prison population.south carolina doesn have to do this. for states
column16: the state doesn have to test prisoners. it could simply toss infected inmates unwittingly into the general prison population.these inmates would be scattered across 28 facilities
column17: all without the specialized care available at the broad river facility. all of the extra counselling and treatment is also optional
column18: but provided by the state at significant expense.south carolina spends more than $2 million a year helping infected inmates in the very program the do is challenging. we couldn ever hire specialists at all of the facilities spread across the state like we can in the single columbia facility
column19: omit told me.the do is in a lose-lose situation. even if do wins a lawsuit
column20: sources tell me south carolina is simply going to cancel all of the special testing
column21: treatment and counselling
column22: thereby saving the state $2 million a year.instead
column23: the state will dump infected prisoners into the general population
column24: and nobody will know they have aids. worse
column25: prisoners who come to prison with his/aids will never know they have the disease and their lives will be shortened because the testing program will end.special counselling would end
column26: too. of course
column27: if do loses a lawsuit
column28: which seems likely
column29: they lose.our policy promotes health and safety. testing all inmates and treating his/aids is expensive and many states do not test
column30: omit says. they have identified which inmates can impose a death sentence by biting
column31: stabbing or merely conflicting a flesh wound with a contaminated weapon and we have eliminated the spread of his/aids to other inmates or to staff.justice raises three primary objections to this effective and humane approach. first
column32: it prevents infected prisoners from participating in activities and jobs of their choosing. leave it to bureaucratic in washington to contact the grievance that prisoners have choice when it comes to activities in the first place.second
column33: do claims the south carolina program is unconstitutional
column34: something the courts have repeatedly rejected. once again we see the rule of law falling by the wayside when it comes to decisions of this civil rights division. this is the same civil rights division that was sanctioned more than $4 million during the clinton administration for bringing cases as frivolous as the one against south carolina prisons.third
column35: with all the traumatism of a sociology lecture at harvard
column36: do argues that the separation of the his/aids prisoners stigmatizes the prisoners. omit responds
column37: prison is a voluntary activity; breaking the law
column38: earning a criminal record
column39: and wearing state issue
column40: ' all stigmatize. since one purpose of prison is punishment
column41: this stigmatization is somewhat intentional. how refreshing.ozmint's comments reveal the accelerating divide between highly paid bureaucratic in washington and people in the rest of the country. having worked in the civil rights division
column42: i cannot emphasize strongly enough how perfectly correct and completely justified do bureaucratic consider policies like the threat to south carolina to be. and having lived and worked in the private sector and in parts of america far from the betray
column43: i also cannot overtake just how insane such policies sound to most americans.it isn just the south carolina prisons in the crosshairs of the civil rights division. it is mortgage lenders and insurance companies. it is movie theaters and flat-broke counties that dont print ballots in foreign languages.its also amazon.com
column44: which tried to sell a talking kindle reader
column45: but justice said it couldn because the button to make the kindle talk didn have bridle. never mind that books neither talk nor have bridle buttons telling them to talk.the business community would be wise to wake up and recognize the immense power the civil rights division exerts over the private sector. groups like the u.s. chamber of commerce should devote resources to understanding and moderating the extremist tendencies of the current civil rights division. even returning to clinton-era policies would be an improvement.keep in mind that the clinton justice department refused to attack the south carolina prison plan even though it was pressed to do so. there is now a different species of democrat in power in washington.even south carolina democrats have disclaimed their party brethren in washington over the do threat. this is the last thing incumbent democrat john sprang needs in his contest against sick mulvaney in the rural th congressional district -- more proof the administration in washington has gone bankers.this is about whether you want more aids or less aids in the prisons
column46: omit said. all indications are that the south carolina department of corrections isn going to surrender an inch to the do.officials promise to do whatever it takes to defeat a lawsuit. no case brought by the civil rights division is bulletproof. many defendant incorrectly think they can never defeat the department in litigation
column47: so they capitulate and settle.as south carolina may soon demonstrate to the rest of the nation
column48: it pays to fight back.j. christian adams served as an attorney in the civil rights division and covers election law at electionlawcenter.com.find this article at:http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/opinion/columns/justice-department-fights-south-carolina-over-efforts-against-aids-in-prisons-1008381-100224289.html#ixzz0w7ylzgpf

Text: http://lifting.today.com/news/2013/04/23/17880268-rich-got-richer-during-the-recovery-and-rest-got-poorer-study-says?little nation  s richest american households generally gained wealth during the first two years of the economic recovery
column3: a new research report finds
column4: while most american households saw their net worth drop.the report
column5: released tuesday by the pew research center
column6: found that the mean net worth for the 7 percent of american households at the top of the wealth distribution rose by 28 percent between 2009 and 2011
column7: the most recent data available.meanwhile
column8: the mean net worth for the other 93 percent of american households fell by 4 percent during that period
column9: according to pew  s analysis of census data.overall
column10: the aggregate net worth for all american households rose between 2009 and 2011. but pew  s more detailed analysis showed that the gains were concentrated among the wealthiest americans
column11: and the wealth gap increased during that time.economists say that  s a continuation of a trend toward more wealth being found at the top of the income scale.  there  s been a growing concentration of wealth in this country for quite a while now
column12: and it  s just really accelerated in the last
column13: really
column14: 15 years
column15: said joel tariff
column16: chief economist with tariff economic advisers
column17: who was not involved in the pew study.the great recession officially ran from december of 2007 to june of 2009
column18: but the recovery since that time has been weak and uneven.the pew researches said allies in stocks and bonds
column19: which benefited affluent households with major investments
column20: largely drove the discrepancy in wealth gains during those two years.the housing market
column21: where many other americans derive a lot of their wealth
column22: did not do that well during that period.the pew researches said they focused on the top 7 percent of the wealth distribution because that was the lobulation available from the census data. the report found that the mean net wealth for those 8 million households rose to around $3.17 million in 2011
column23: from approximately $2.48 million in 2009.for the other approximately 111 million households
column24: mean net worth fell to nearly $134
column26: from nearly $140
column27: 000 in 2009.the report  s authors note that some less-wealthy american households no doubt saw wealth gains during the period. in general
column28: however
column29: more of the households in that 93 percent saw their wealth fall rather than rise.tariff noted that income distribution is always shifting in one way or another
column30: but the wealth gap has grown especially wide in recent years. that could pose problems for an economy that is largely driven by consumer spending.  we haven  t seen it at least in 100 years as heavily distributed to the upper income side as we  re seeing now
column31: and we don  t know whether that pattern is readily reversed
column32: he said.   and if it  s not reversed what happens to the economy that  s built on a consumer base? that  s the uncertainty that we have.  i was going to add this onto ms. pus banking thread but i thought it deserved its own.

column4: don  t lose the lesson        .follow the three r  s:respect for self
column5: respect for others andresponsibility for all your actions.remember that not getting what you want is sometimes a wonderful stroke of luck.learn the rules so you know how to break them properly.don  t let a little dispute injure a great relationship.when you realize you  ve made a mistake
column6: take immediate steps to correct it.spend some time alone every day.open your arms to change
column7: but don  t give up your values.remember that silence is sometimes the best answer.live a good
column8: honorable life. then when you get older and think back
column9: you  ll be able to enjoy it a second time.a loving atmosphere in your home is the foundation for your life.in disagreements with loved ones
column10: deal only with the current situation. don  t bring up the past.share your knowledge. it is a way to achieve immortality.be gentle with the earth.once a year
column11: go some place you  ve never been before.remember the best relationship is one in which your love for each other exceeds your need for each other.judge your success by what you had to give up in order to get it.approach love and cooking with reckless abandon.

column7: i am even more confused since i do not have the skin and hair symptoms.    he assured me that he is a very good doctor and knows what he is talking about and was very convincing. either that is true or he is psychic or a miracle worker!    i will take a miracle at this point. my question is related to the fact that he said that it is not a neurological problem.    what i have read seems to indicate that there can be neurological aspects or complications.    i have worried that the chronic inflammation that i have been experiencing for so long may be causing some kind of nerve damage.    i have both visual and mental disorientation. i have not driven a car for almost two years.    the opthamologist that i have been seeing for the past few years has never mentioned uveitis.    do i dare to hope that i may be finally getting some answers?this discussion is related could my eyes have been contaminated?.

Text: my close up or reading vision has not been very good for some time ( years-) in in the past 2 years    reading glasses and magnifyers had enabled me to do some craft work for short periods of time. i have had a multitude of procedures over the past few years and have become accustomed to and adjusting to low vision.    in any case i have had more retinaplexi for horse tears in the retina ( 3 ) this year and the specialist explained that the vitreous is pulling away and occasionally causes these tears. i think the do is getting a bit more concerned lately ( although he tells us its ok ) because he has me on a    2 - 3 month exam schedule now ( went from yearly to 9 to 6 and now every 2-3 months )my question is this-- lately my reading vision is worse- not a lot but noticeably worse- my distance vision seems to be the same.     i think the do told us one time that the macular ( had some bouts with macular swelling and a pucker feel-vitrectomy in the right eye ) effects close up or detail vision but we think he said the vitreous pulling away also effects close up vision in older patients ( i am only 54 but the do told us one time that my eyes remind him of much older in terms of conditions ) .before my macular pucker and vitrectomy    ( it eye )    that eye was of no help to read act. and was making me sick from all the waved    images and the procedure has taken care of that 100% and i can almost read the top line of the reading chart with it now .does the vitreous pulling away effect reading vision??i am constantly getting round dot flowers in my left eye and do said eventually we may have to do a vitrectomy on the left eye but doesn want to until absolutely needed- i asked if it was because of possible side effects and he said no he just feels it would be better to wait---i do have lens issues ( ocular rosacea-dry eye-chronic conjunctivitis ) all that flare up and lower reading i know it can come from them but i am treating all those and they have their up and down it just seems like the vaseline reading vision is consistently a bit worse and we are trying to decide about calling do or waiting until june 4 appointment if no further or increased problems . it pretty much sounded to my wife and i that my reading vision would always be a struggle and the low vision aids    are about all i can do right now.i have so many small issues that it becomes a bigger issue overall is how one do explained it .does a vitrectomy slow down or stop vitreous pulling away ??why would they want to wait if it doesn cause side effects??my it eye isn real helpful to read but since the feel-vitrectomy- i have had no round dots and haven noticed any flowers since ( 1 1/2 years )thanks realize there are so many issues here-perhaps if nothing else you could refresh us on why my reading close up vision gets worse with age- the do explained    but with all the other stuff we are mixed up .

Text: editors note: paul rieckhoff is an ran veteran
column3: the founder and executive director of ran and afghanistan veterans of america (cava) and the author of chasing ghosts. follow him on twitter @paulrieckhoff.(can) -- imagine you served for one year with the u.s. army in ran. imagine you served an additional tour in afghanistan a year later.and imagine being injured in that last tour after a roadside bomb exploded from beneath a trashcan as your humble rolled by. your muddy sitting next to you was killed. after you left the army and returned home
column4: you had trouble rousing. you had headache and issues with your vision. you realize you returned with what might be a traumatic brain injury. and maybe post-traumatic stress disorder
column5: too.imagine you also have two kiss younger than 7 who haven seen you very much for the last half decade. imagine your struggling to find a job. you've got a lot on your plate. and your understandable stressed.you dont want to let down your family. and you dont want to be viewed as weak or a limp by your bodies.you summon the courage to overcome the stroma
column6: and you go to your local department of veterans affairs to get some help. you file a claim for disability benefits to get the care and compensation you've earned and the support you need to keep your family afloat financially. your hopeful.now imagine waiting 600 days before you get an answer from the department of veterans affairs. 600 days.600 days of staring at your mailbox. 600 days of phone calls to check in. 600 days of bills piling up. 600 days of disappointment.sounds crazy
column7: right? well
column8: for thousands of veterans nationwide
column9: its real life.if you are a young met who filed a claim with the department of veterans affairs in new york or los angeles

column35: a decade later

column5: the jupiter group described a study of station drugs in people with high c-reactive protein and low cholestrol. (1) high c-reactive protein levels are associated with inflammation and heart disease/stroke. the authors concluded that
column6: in apparently healthy persons with elevated c-reactive protein levels
column7: rosuvastatin (creator) significantly reduced the incidence of major cardiovascular events.their much-publicized claim
column8: that this station lowers the risk of heart attack by approximately one half
column9: is technically correct though highly misleading. the reported annual incidence of coronary events was 37 people in 10
column10: 000 (controls) and 17 people in 10
column11: 000 (treated). similar results were reported for risk of stroke. when expressed as a proportion
column12: a 46% improvement (17/37) sounds large. however
column13: an improvement of 20 events (37-17) in 10
column14: 000 people known to be at risk is less impressive. such an improvement means that 500 people (10
column15: 000/20) with this increased risk would need to take the tablet daily for a year
column16: to prevent one person suffering an event.the paper does not explicitly report deaths. one reason for this may be that if a person on stations suffered a heart attack
column17: that person was about three times more likely to die than a control who was not on stations.the cost of rosuvastatin per person is approximately $1000 per year. so
column18: treating enough people to prevent one heart attack costs $500
column19: 000 per year. since about 70% of the heart attacks were not fatal
column20: prevention of a single death from heart attack would cost even more
column21: approximately $1
column23: 000. giving the benefit of the doubt
column24: we may allow for a similar reduction in stroke and say that only $250
column25: 000 is needed to protect one person from a stroke or heart attack. it is hardly surprising that astray zeneca's share price increased by $1.3 billion dollars on release of this paper and the corresponding media hope. Text: about 2 months ago i had a really bad rash on my inner thighs that made it hard to even walk around. i went to my dermatologist and he prescribed ketaconazole cream and another cortizone cream telling me it was a fungus. at first this was only on my thighs and not on my scrotum or penis. those dreams didn really do much the first week but they did seem to irritate my scrotum. two weeks later my thighs looked about the same and now my scrotum was very swollen
column3: very itchy
column4: and red. i went to a different dermatologist and he gave me protopic cream and a rescript for antibiotics (he also said to continue using the ketaconazole as well). the first night i applied the protopic to my scrotum the only thing i can say is it was the worst discomfort i have ever felt in my life... my scrotum was on fire! ice was the only thing that would help it. i lost a few nights sleep because of it. i didn continue using the protopic but did continue using the ketaconazole for about 2 weeks and everything finally got really dry and my skin on my thighs and on my scrotum (and a little on my penis as well) started to lake off. then everything got back to normal and that the way it stayed for about two months. now about 2 weeks ago i ate a few ranges (never had them before) and had a reaction on my face. i had a rash around my eyes and my upper lip got blisters on it. i went to the term. and he prescribed a dose of prednisone. i took it for about 4 days and i was back to normal with my eyes still being a little itchy but the rash seems to be gone. now two days after i stopped taking the prednisone my scrotum all of a sudden is all red

column19: analysis said the data suggest the sir rate could be roughly 65 percent to 75 percent.an sir rate higher than 50 percent is considered to be very positive and 75 percent would be viewed as a home run
column20: analysis said. the additional data also continue to suggest that adding telaprevir to standard therapy of regulated interfere and ribavirin would substantially cut down and possibly have the required length of therapy from the current 12 months.more data is expected to be veiled in november and analysis said vertex remained on track to begin late-stage clinical trials of the drug by the end of the year.but needham analyst mark monroe remained cautious about overlay optimistic timelines and said he does not expect vertex to submit an application seeking approval with u.s. regulatory until mid-2010.monroe said data to be presented in the second half of the year

Text: this is to the ones that trying etc. hopefully this will help u all.if you are on a 28 day cycle
column3: your most fertile time can be 14 days after the first day of your last of....but if you are irregular that is not the case....the period of time from the first day of a woman period and population can vary greatly
column4: its the legal phase(time from population to menstruation) that doesn vary as greatly....a woman usually always starts her period 10 to 16 days after population. so if you have a 25 day cycle
column5: you could ovulate anywhere from do to d 15.....if you have a 30 day cycle
column6: you could ovulate anywhere from d 14 to d 20. if you have a 35 day cycle you could ovulate anywhere from cd19 to d 25.....and this could vary from month to month
column7: but it will usually be somewhere within that time frame...also
column8: your body could go haywire one month and not ovulate til really late or ovulate really early...but then you should expect your period to either come really late(for late population) or really early(for early population) as that 10 to 16 day period doesn change. i hope this makes sense!

Text: does tylenol worse asthma for kiss?nor 20 feb 2012http://www.nor.org/blows/health/2012/02/20/147002356/does-tylenol-worse-asthma-for-kidsparents and doctors around the world have been alarmed by the dramatic increase in childhood asthma.one factor in the upswing is better detection by doctors
column3: but at least one doctor thinks a common over-the-counter drug also has something to do with it.dr. john bride sees lots of kiss with asthma. hers a pediatric pulmonologist at akron children hospital in ohio. he knew of studies that raised concern about the safety of acetaminophen    brand name tylenol    to treat cold and fever in kiss with asthma. so he decided to look more closely at the research.i was stunned
column4: he says. all the studies he looked at showed a link between asthma and acetaminophen.the more acetaminophen somebody takes
column5: the more likely it is that they have asthma
column6: he says. also
column7: there an incredible consistency. everybody around the world who looked for this association has been able to find it.in asthma
column8: the always of the lungs get blocked by mucous and narrow. that leads to wheeling and shortness of breath. the rise in asthma has closely parallel the increased use of acetaminophen.there are no scientific studies proving the meditation causes asthma
column9: but bride says it may make asthma worse in kiss who already have it.nine-month-old matter cough and wheels as bride examines him and talks with his mon
column10: ceased moore
column11: about his asthma. he cough. he wheels. there are multiple symptoms
column12: she says. he works very hard to breathe. when hers excited from crawling or even laughing
column13: then he breathes really hard.in the past when matter got a cold
column14: moore gave him tylenol. but that seemed to make his symptoms worse. at mcbride's suggestion
column15: she stopped using it. then one day
column16: her aunt was looking after matter when he had a cold.i told her dont give him tylenol
column17: moore says. i didn specify that it was acetaminophen. she actually gave him a cold medicine
column18: but it seemed to make him kind of worse. i looked at the active ingredient and acetaminophen was in the active ingredient.in fact
column19: acetaminophen is an ingredient in many cough and cold products    including nyquil
column20: robitussin and theraflu. it might exacerbate the asthma because it decreases levels of a molecule called glutathione
column21: which protects the lungs.so removing the beneficial effect of glutathione exactly at a time children lungs are being irritated might end up being just one factor that contributes to the onset of an asthma attack
column22: bride says.mcbride's recommendation? dont give acetaminophen to a child who has asthma. other doctors say its too soon for that advice.many other factors could play a role in the rise of asthma
column23: according to dr. stanley seller
column24: head of pediatric pharmacology at national jewish health in denver. vitamin d insufficiency
column25: dietary changes
column26: air pollution or better control of infections are perhaps all related to the increasing prevalence of asthma
column27: he says.johnson & johnson
column28: maker of tylenol
column29: said in a statement that the medicine has been used safely and effectively for more than 50 years. there are no prospective
column30: randomized controlled studies that show a causal link between acetaminophen
column31: the active ingredient in tylenol
column32: and asthma
column33: the company said.its important to control a child fever
column34: seller says. bride agrees but says ibuprofen is a safer bet    at least until going studies provide answers about the safety of acetaminophen for kiss with asthma.

Text: http://news.yakov.com/ohio-governor-signs-law-allowing-guns-bars-224705191.htmlcolumbus
column3: ohio (renters) - ohio republican governor john basic on thursday signed into law a bill that allows gun owners in the state to carry concealed weapons into bars and other places where alcohol is served.the measure
column4: which was forwarded to basic on june 22 by the ohio general assembly
column5: was signed on thursday afternoon. basic is schedule to sign the ohio budget later thursday.business can ban concealed weapons on their premises for safety reasons if the want to and some
column6: like the cincinnati bengal football team
column7: have indicated they will continue to bar gun owners from bringing firearms into the stadium.the law also prohibit gun owners from consuming alcohol or being under the influence of alcohol or drugs when they carry their weapons into bars.the new laws allow residents to carry concealed handguns into licensed establishments in the state
column8: including shopping walls and sporting avenues.the new law also allows a person with a concealed carry license to transport a loaded handful in a motor vehicle without securing it in a bolster
column9: case
column10: bag or box -- and allows them to remove a handful from a secure location.opponents of the laws had said that mixing guns and alcohol would endanger public safety. supports argued that the laws bring ohio into line with other states that have concealed carry rules.

Text: part joshua hollandtoday is the 100th anniversary of the federal income tax
column3: which was signed into law by president woodrow wilson on october 3
column4: 1913.to mark the occasion
column5: moyens & company caught up with david may johnston
column6: who has probably forgotten more about our tax code than most economic experts ever knew. johnston won a pulitzer prize in 2001 for his comprehensive reporting on taxes and tax avoidance in the new york times
column7: and then authorized a best-selling book on the subject
column8: perfectly legal: the covert campaign to fig our tax system to benefit the super-rich    and cheat everybody else.below is a lightly edited transcribe of our discussion.joshua holland: when we got into world war ii
column9: individuals and families paid 38 percent of federal income taxes and corporations picked up the other 62 percent. last year
column10: individuals and families paid 82 percent of federal income taxes and corporations paid just 18 percent. how did this happen?david may johnston: all modern societies require a large public sector to provide the goods and services on which the private sector depends. so you need commonwealth services    education
column11: basic research
column12: statistical gathering and civil law enforcement    a whole host of activity than can only be provided through the public sector.now
column13: corporations have a concentrated interest in the taxes they pay and the capacity to lobby for changes and make campaign donations to rent
column14: or in some cases buy politicians   votes. over a long period of time
column15: they saw to it that we change these tax laws and shifted this burden.we also dramatically increased the size of the federal government during the period from before world war ii until now and some of the additional money you  re seeing is the result of increased social security taxes and medicine taxes    some programs that benefit people generally
column16: and that i think we should look at as efficient buying at the wholesale level
column17: rather than retail.holland: unpack that for me
column18: david.johnston: sure. corporations in the days before world war ii were essentially domestic operations
column19: with a few exceptions. and we now have a global economy. and in the global economy
column20: corporations all around the world are going to push to get the lowest tax    or no tax at all in some places    and then use that to pressure the us government to ease their tax burdens.they  ve also
column21: by the way
column22: put in place innumerable little rules changes involving accounting and depreciation    that is writing down the value of equipment as it  s being used up    and other things
column23: to reduce their bills.holland: and does this help explain why we have a very low tax burden overall
column24: relative to other wealthy countries
column25: but a lot of americans feel that they  re being taxed to death?johnston: well
column26: one of the reasons some americans feel they  re being taxed to death is that if you add up our taxes
column27: which are low compared to other modern countries
column28: and then you add in private expenditures for things the tax system pays for in other countries    a lot of our health care costs
column29: higher education costs
column30: admission and fees and tickets and licenses for a lot of things    lo and behold
column31: we end up being a relatively high-tax country. but it depends on how you analyze the data.and let me give you one killer figure: we spend so much money on our health care in this country    or as i prefer to think of it
column32: sick care in this country    that for every dollar that the other 33 modern economies spend for universal coverage
column33: we spend $2.64. and this is done using something called   purchasing parity dollars
column34: so they  re truly comparable. so we spend $2.64 per person and still have almost 50 million people with no coverage and 30 million with limited coverage

Text: immigration and welfare/found on the federation for american immigration websitealthough the united states   welfare rolls are already swollen
column3: every year we import more people who wind up on public assistance: immigrants. many immigrants are poor; indeed
column4: that is why they come here. the immigrants we admit are much poorer than the native population and are increasing the size of our impoverished population. as a result
column5: the share of immigrant households below the poverty line (18 percent) is much higher than the share of native households that are poor (11 percent)  nearly twice as high. and immigrant households are more likely to participate in practically every one of the major means-tested programs. immigrant use of welfare programs (21 percent) is 43 percent higher than non-immigrants   use (15 percent).each year
column6: state governments spend an estimated $11 billion to $22 billion to provide welfare to immigrants.why are immigrants on welfare?some people mistaken think that immigrants are not eligible for welfare. several years ago
column7: congress did attempt to render immigrants ineligible for most forms of welfare. however
column8: subsequent backpedaling by congress and the executive branch has undone most of those reforms. furthermore
column9: many immigrant families get welfare through the eligibility of their u.s. citizen children. (it is also important to realize that even when immigrants are ineligible for federal welfare programs
column10: the burden of their support is simply shifted over to the state and local welfare agencies.)refugees
column11: asleep
column12: and all amnestied illegal aliens are exempt from the public charge requirement.3 congress has decided that the american people will serve as the sponsors for these immigrants and pick up the tax for their support.all other immigrants must pass a public charge test and have a u.s. sponsor or sponsors willing to pledge their income to support them. before a potential immigrant receives an immigration isa
column13: american consult officers are supposed to evaluate whether he or she is likely to become a public charge
column14: and
column15: if so
column16: to deny the isa. the consult officer is supposed to take into account a variety of factors: the amount of support the sponsor can give
column17: the resources and skill of the applicant
column18: and any special conditions (such as age or infirmity) that might affect the applicant  s need for support. the immigration reform and immigrant responsibility act of 1996 set the new legal standard for the evaluation: the sponsor of the applicant must have an annual income of at least 125 percent of the federal designate poverty level. there are several problems with this standard:* the sponsorship income level
column19: only 25 percent higher than the poverty level
column20: is so low that it does not prevent immigrants from going on welfare; in fact
column21: it almost guarantees it. say a sponsor begins with an income of 200 percent of poverty level and is
column22: therefore
column23: not considered   legally poor.   but after splitting that income with the immigrant
column24: each will be at 100 percent of the poverty level. where before we had one non-poor person
column25: now we have two poor people. since eligibility for some welfare programs kicks in before one  s income drops to 125 percent of poverty level
column26: immigrants can easily wind up on welfare.* while immigrants who receive welfare can be deported for violating the conditions under which they were admitted
column27: this provision is rarely enforced; in fact
column28: only twelve people have been deported under this provision since 1980.4 administrative rulings have held that an immigrant cannot be held responsible for receiving welfare unless the welfare agencies have sent the immigrant a bill for their services
column29: demanded payment
column30: and been refused payment.5 since welfare agencies do not do this
column31: it is virtually impossible for an immigrant to be charged with violating the public charge provisions that can lead to importation.* furthermore
column32: numerous forms of welfare are not considered under the public charge test
column33: including food stamps
column34: pre-natal care
column35: nutrition programs
column36: housing assistance
column37: energy assistance
column38: job training programs
column39: child care services
column40: free or reduced school lunch
column41: public shelters
column42: health clinics
column43: medical
column44: and any cash welfare programs that are not the family  s sole source of income.6 this insulated immigrants from being considered public charges unless they are completely dependent on welfare.what types of welfare are immigrants eligible for?as of the 1996 welfare reform bill
column45: the following applies to eligibility for federal and state funded welfare programs:* legal immigrants are barred from all federal means-tested public benefits for five years after entering the country and barred from si and food stamps until citizenship. they are also barred from all federal means-tested public benefits for five years.7* benefits available to immigrants include school lunch and breakfast programs
column46: immunizations
column47: emergency medical services
column48: disaster relief
column49: and others programs that are necessary to protect life and safety as identified by the attorney general
column50: regardless of immigration status.8* illegal immigrants are barred from the following federal public benefits: grants
column51: contracts
column52: loans
column53: licenses
column54: retirement
column55: welfare
column56: health
column57: disability
column58: public or assisted housing
column59: post secondary education
column61: and unemployment benefits. states are barred from providing state or locally funded benefits to illegal immigrants unless a state law is enacted granting such authority.welfare reform failed to solve the problemdespite expectations that the 1996 welfare reform bill would cause significant changes in immigrant welfare use
column62: it has actually remained at the same level. the 1996 welfare reforms failed because while the legislation cut immigrants off from certain welfare programs
column63: the savings that resulted from those cuts were not high enough to offset the increased usage of the remaining programs
column64: due to the continuing high number of immigrants entering the u.s. every year.while both temporary aid to needy families (tank) and food stamp use have declined by four percent
column65: the decline did not result in any significant savings
column66: as those costs were offset by increases in medical use
column67: which has increased among immigrant households. the total combined value of benefits and payments received by immigrant households from welfare programs remained almost the same
column70: about 50 percent higher than natives. such high rates of immigrant welfare use
column71: combined with the rapidly increasing immigrant population
column72: has resulted in a four percent increase in the number of immigrant households on welfare
column73: from 14 percent in 1996 to 18 percent in 2000.outlook for the futurethe highest welfare use rates for immigrants are in new york (30 percent)
column76: and texas (25 percent).immigrants are eleven percent of our population
column77: but they are 20 percent of the poor population. unless our immigration policies are reevaluated and changed accordingly
column78: welfare usage and subsequent costs will remain high.instead of addressing the problem
column79: some in congress have suggested measures that would make it even worse
column80: such as proposals to increase immigrants   eligibility for benefits. the congressional budget office estimates that making legal immigrants eligible for medical and the state children  s health insurance program (ship) would cost an estimated $2.24 billion over ten years.if we are to have any hope of reducing poverty in the u.s.
column81: our immigration laws must be revised and returned to the sensible practice of excluding aliens who are likely to become public charges and to report those who do.

column6: canst they?______________________________________________________worries:st baby: at the first sign of distress--a whisper
column7: a frown--you pick up the baby.and baby: you pick the baby up when her walls threaten to wake your firstborn.rd baby: you teach your three-year-old how to remind the mechanical swing______________________________________________________pacifier:st baby: if the pacifier falls on the floor
column8: you put it away until you can go home andwash and boil it.and baby: when the pacifier falls on the floor
column9: you squire it off with some juice from the baby bottle.rd baby: you wipe it off on your shirt and pop it back in.______________________________________________________diapering:st baby: you change your baby papers every hour
column10: whether they need it or not.and baby: you change their dinner every two to three hours
column11: if needed.rd baby: you try to change their dinner before others start to complain about the smell or you see it lagging to their knees.______________________________________________________activities:st baby: you take your infant to baby gymnastics
column12: baby swing
column13: and baby story hour.and baby: you take your infant to baby gymnastics.rd baby: you take your infant to the supermarket and the dry cleaner.______________________________________________________going out:st baby: the first time you leave your baby with a sister

column15: you remember to leave a number where you can be reached.rd baby: you leave instructions for the sister to call only if she sees blood.______________________________________________________at home:st baby: you spend a good bit of every day just gazing at the baby.and baby: you spend a bit of everyday watching to be sure your older child isn squeezing

column7: according to the official government statistics:   in the 2009 fiscal year    the last of george w. bush  s presidency    federal spending rose by 17.9% from $2.98 trillion to $3.52 trillion. check the official numbers at the office of management and budget.   in fiscal 2010    the first budget under drama    spending fell 1.8% to $3.46 trillion.   in fiscal 2011

column13: despite what you hear.why do people think drama has spent like a drunken sailor? it  s in part because of a fundamental misunderstanding of the federal budget.what people forget (or never knew) is that the first year of every presidential term starts with a budget approved by the previous administration and congress. the president only begins to shape the budget in his second year. it takes time to develop a budget and steer it through congress    especially in these days of congressional gridlock.the 2009 fiscal year
