Text: every action a person takes in the united states is regulated by the government. many of these regulations go unnoticed. but think about every action you take and the bureau-   cry tic agency regulating it. from brushing your teeth to watering your lawn
column3: the government has intruder and regulated every action you take. but how did we end up in a society that has allowed itself to be regulated across the board?we live in an age where the government fears the people. and frightfully so. they rustle our paychecks
column4: ballot combine corporations against the wishes of the public
column5: and send our money overseas to painless causes. clearly
column6: this government has taken many actions that are not supported by the people that pay for them.many people argue that we are rewarded richly for government differing via public schools
column7: defense and road systems
column8: to name just a few government projects. but many of these services
column9: if not all
column10: could be provided with better quality and cheaper prices through the private sector.which leads one to wonder why we never hear privatization advocated by our politicians? why should people always look to government for solutions to modern day problems such as the by spill clean
column11: instead of private companies that could do the same work better and cheaper?wise economists from the austrian school of thought blame this blind support of government intervention on a phenomenon known as   the people  s romance.   this phenomenon shows people are drawn to government in a way that allows government to take actions most would object to if they understood what truly free society is. if the average citizen was to closely examine the complete control government wields over one  s life
column12: investigation the effects of each nancy state regulation
column13: they would most likely object to the power government has.through   the people  s romance
column14: the government consolidated power by controlling local points in one  s life. people become dependent
column15: so they think
column16: on the plethoric of government services that are provided. government officials exploit the services to win support in elections. most politicians argue expanding certain services to further consolidate power
column17: but rarely do we see a politician argue privatization of these services. to private would mean that the government would lose access to influence every facet of your life.currently
column18: the people  s romance   is on the rise in america. with the drama administration  s expansion of power through insane amounts of frivolous spending via   the stimulus   and the complete takeover of the health care sector
column19: government influence over one  s life seems to be the only thing growing in 2010. the government would rather hide the fact that they have mixed the economy through their incessant
column20: destructive intervention then risk losing the ever-expanding control they wield over society.if we want a society that is free of an encroaching government that impedes individual freedom
column21: we must look to the private sector for answers to today  s problems not to government bureaucratic interested in gaining more power. we must remember that only the private sector can deliver the results that government has prove time and again it is unable to do. and above all
column22: the private sector removed bad business actors from the marketplace efficiently while government drops them up by failing them out with your money and the money of future generations.there is nothing wrong with supporting government. but there is something very wrong with a government that wants to regulate your every action. don  t let your romantic feelings of government cloud your lens of viewing what congress and drama are really after.adam likely is the editor-in-chief of netrightdaily.com.http://www.papa.com/opinion/action-49672-every-government.html

Text: we have a 7 year old daughter who exhibits an inability to south herself to sleep.    we have tried rewards - punishments.     it is almost like she just can  t let go of the day.    we have to be within her sight at bed or she has a fit.    we have gone from sitting on the bed to the floor to the door way to the halfway but just canst seem to get past this.    some nights this could take an hour or two.    we have done night lights.    she wears my watch to bed for comfort.    we are so frustrated in her inability to go to sleep.    what we find astonishing is she goes 110% all the time and just can  t seem to shut down or even slow down.    we have recently started a   daily journal   in an effort to reap the day so that we can   remember it.    this seemed to have helped but only slightly.    we do have a very structures routine in an efforts to slow the day down and bring it to a close.    that is bath at 7:30 bed and book by 8 and lights out by 8:15.    if we can get    her to be still and quite for just 30 seconds  ..i mean it 30 seconds she out.    but getting that 30 seconds is sometimes the most trying time of the day.a little history i am divorced and she is a result of my first marriage.    she has been and continues to go to therapy weekly for this as well as anger management issues.    she has some abandonment issues we are attempting to work through.    i have recently   discovered   that when she was at her      real   dad  s (when we had shared custody) he would put her to bed and then go out locking the doors and not come back for hours.    i can  t even imagine how terrified she must have felt.    no matter how much we reassure her that we would never leave her that we will keep her safe
column3: there is no end in sight.    she can wake up 2-3 times a night and once she hears or see  s us she goes right back to sleep.    problem is we are not so lucky      i would appreciate any advise/help that would allow her to go to sleep and us to get a full night  s sleep.we have made certain that when she is not with us she knows how to contact us no matter what and that she can call no matter what.    problem here is
column4: we live in the country and her dad puts the phone up.    she insists on being with her dad
column5: problem here is when he has her he never around she is always passed off to grand or an aunt or uncle to tell the truth i feel better if she is with them at least then i know she is safe.     but we need to find out how to help her turn off the day and show her that it is ok to sleep.    please i am begging any help or suggestions would be greatly appreciated.petty

Text: my son was adopted international at 14 months. at 15 months we had him evacuated (he only knew russian)and he met the requirements for early intervention for speech and after 6 months he joined a play group for 2 his. once a week. after 18 months of services with early intervention my son tested out of everything--they did the an extensive testing--speech--of-it -pay
column3: just about 4 months ago my husband and i signed my son up for pre-school so he would have interaction with other children his age. 2 weeks after being in the pre-school he was bitten by another child--well
column4: now we are having issues with my son biting. he has bitten x since he first started with the program9since he received his first bite) and is now suspended for a day with the program. a month ago my son met with the sensory person(an outside consult recommended from the school) the outcome was that my son had some transition issues and it was recommended that the school have pictures for him to what he is going to be doing next--something my husband and i did with him at an early age do to the language gap so he could understand or communicate with us. i am not sure if the school has followed up on this but--the consult also mentioned that my son needs sensory stimulation--recommendations were made for that. my son attempted to bite me once and was immediately put into timeout and his favorite toy was taken away--he has never attempted to bite--he attempted to hit once and i followed that same procedure and he has never attempted it again. at home he has the normal 3 or. old issues and they are immediately addressed. i can take my son anywhere and my friends are always commenting how good my son is. now i hear a completely different thing from school and i dont see any of the behavior that the school is mentioning. his teacher are great at giving feedback which i like and i dont want my son to be thrown out of this school. tomorrow my son and i will be doing some role playing and working on how he can express his frustration --i am not sure how that will go but
column5: since he has been suspended it will not be a fun filled day of play for him--i will remind him that he could be playing with toys at school--but. with not seeing this behavior i dont want to put all the blame on him because i dont know if all of the events leading up to the bite are all his fault--the bite definitely is--but at 3.5 years of age he is still working on developing how to express his frustration. any advice or suggestions will be very appreciated.thank you for your time!trial

column23: researches selected 100 patients with diagnosed pp
column24: 100 patients with alzheimer disease (ad)
column25: and 100 healthy patients with an average age of 65 years from the clinical research in neurology (chin) database from the memory university school of medicine. they examined the patients   blood samples to look at vitamin d blood levels.   vitamin d insufficiency   was defined as having vitamin d blood levels below 30 monograms per milliliter and   vitamin d deficiency   was defined as vitamin d blood levels below 20 monograms per millilter.the researches found that 55% of the pp patients had vitamin d insufficiency compared to 41% of ad patients and 36% of controls. regarding vitamin d deficiency

column17: a week before the da issued a public recall.since hip is a common ingredient in almost all processes foods

column21: which kills the salmonella. still

column3: and    straight on side of index finger in addition to sides of feet near big toe. i had tingling sensations and uncomfortable ever since. i have uncomfortable tingling in my left arm and left wrist
column4: it was difficult to type with both hands without a weird uncomfortable sensation for first 3 days including intermittent pins and needles in both my feet. after th or th day the weird sensations in hands and arms turned to pain. i still have slight tingling in my right hand and softness in right upper arm is still there. when i walk and swing my arms
column5: i can feel the same odd sensations in both of my arms to hands. fine motor skill are slightly weakened in the right hand particularly because of uncomfortable sensations which i found out from an md to be due to radial nerve damage as a result of acupuncture. there is slight tingling behind my left knee as i walk and when i try to point my toes there will be an uncomfortable tingling sensation in my feet. these effects really concern me as i have been always healthy for all my life and have never had any prior health problems at the level of this severity previously. these sensations are uncomfortable and unbearable and i can only hope they do not continue.    i have pain in hands just in tying this question. my question is: do you think it is possible to make a full recovery? feel free to comment on anything else..look forward to your input
